Presence: a unique characteristic in educational virtual environments

Presence: a unique characteristic in educational virtual environments

  • Tassos A. Mikropoulos1 

Virtual Reality volume 10, pages197–206(2006)Cite this article

  • 1027 Accesses

  • 61 Citations

  • Metrics details

Abstract

This article investigates the effect of presence on learning outcomes in educational virtual environments (EVEs) in a sample of 60 pupils aged between 11 and 13 years. We study the effect of personal presence, social presence and participant’s involvement on certain learning outcomes. We also investigate if the combination of the participant’s representation model in the virtual environment (VE) with the way it is presented gives a higher sense of presence that contributes to learning outcomes. Our results show that the existence of an avatar as the pupils’ representation enhanced presence and helped them to successfully perform their learning tasks. The pupils had a high sense of presence for both cases of the EVE presentation, projection on a wall and through a head mounted display (HMD). Our socialized virtual environment seems to play an important role in learning outcomes. The pupils had a higher sense of presence and completed their learning tasks more easily and successfully in the case of their egocentric representation model using the HMD.

Introduction

Describing virtual reality (VR), philosophers, sociologists, psychologists and computer scientists clearly state or imply the sense of presence as the key feature of virtual environments (VEs) (Mikropoulos and Strouboulis 2004). Presence is considered to be an important attribute in VR applications to psychology, medicine, therapy and rehabilitation, communication, entertainment, arts, training, etc. Although there is no much research in the educational domain, presence also seems to play an important role in educational virtual environments (EVEs).

Presence, in relation to synthetic environments, has been defined by many authors. According to Heeter (1992), “a sense of presence in a virtual world derives from feeling like you exist within but as a separate entity from a virtual world that also exists”. Lombard and Ditton (1997) define presence as the perceptual illusion of non-mediation, the subjective perception that a mediated experience seems very much that it is not mediated. Waterworth and Waterworth (2003) suggest that presence has a biological purpose, defining it as the feeling a conscious organism experiences when immersed in a concrete external world]. Slater (2003) suggests “presence is about form, the extent to which the unification of simulated sensory data and perceptual processing produces a coherent place that you are in and in which there may be the potential for you to act”, distinguishing presence from immersion, involvement, emotional response and degree of interest. Although there are some differences among the above descriptions, researchers agree with the description of presence as “the sense of being there”.

Trying to describe presence, researchers propose theories and develop taxonomies. Following the definitions of presence, we believe that presence as non-mediation, exclusive presence and estimation theory can be considered as theoretical models. The first model follows the definition given by Lombard and Ditton (1997). Exclusive presence is in accordance with the suggestion of Slater et al. (1994) of ‘being there’ and Biocca (1997) states, “at one point of time, users can be said to feel as if they are physically present in only one of three places: the physical environment, the virtual environment, or the imaginal environment”. Estimation theory is proposed by Sheridan (1999), who, from a philosophical point of view, distinguishes objective and subjective reality. He states “we can never truly know objective reality, but are continuously making and refining a mental model which estimates reality, based on our senses and interaction with that reality”.

Concerning presence taxonomies, we believe that Heeter’s (1992) three dimensions of presence; personal, social and environmental presence, cover and generalise other later perspectives.

One of the most important subjects in presence research is the factors, attributes, results and consequences of presence. These are useful and applicable in practical situations and designate the influence of ‘being there’ in VR applications. Researchers try to describe the factors of presence clearly, in order to study it and investigate the sense of presence in VR applications. For that reason, a number of both objective and subjective methods have been developed. Objective measurements can be categorised as behavioural and physiological, the users’ electric brain activity being an example (Mikropoulos et al. 2004). Concerning subjective measurements, a variety of questionnaires have been constructed by many groups (Slater et al. 1994; Witmer and Singer 1998; Schubert et al. 1999; Kim and Biocca 1997; Lessiter et al. 2000; Lombard and Ditton 2000). Although there are similarities and differences among the questionnaires, authors form three major groups of questions, those with form variables, content variables, and participant characteristics. The first group concerns sensory modality, system characteristics such as immersion, interactivity and feedback, and free navigation. Content variables refer to social realism and the nature of task or activity in the virtual environment. Finally, participant characteristics refer to prior experience with the medium, age, etc. Most of the researchers choose a questionnaire and use it as a whole or some parts of it in order to detect presence in specific applications. For the present work we use some questions to investigate the sense of presence, following the statement of Slater (1999) statement saying that presence can be estimated by, “the extent to which participants, after the VE experience, remember it as having visited a place rather than just having seeing images generated by a computer”.

The aim of this article is to argue that the sense of presence is a unique characteristic of EVEs that contributes to positive learning outcomes. The next section is a literature review of EVEs conducted to investigate if research connects presence or factors of presence with learning outcomes. The third section presents an EVE for history teaching and learning aiming to connect presence with learning outcomes and the article closes with a discussion of personal, social presence and the user’s involvement with the EVE in relation to learning outcomes.

Educational virtual environments

An educational virtual environment (EVE) or virtual learning environment (VLE) can be defined as a virtual environment that has one or more educational objectives, pedagogical metaphors, provides users with experiences they would otherwise not be able to experience in the physical world and leads to the attainment of specific learning outcomes.

Learning in VR has been proposed since 1990, when Bricken (1990) specified natural semantics and cognitive presence as the main features of virtual environments and constructivism as the theoretical model supporting EVEs. Helsel (1992) proposed a conceptual orientation to VR concerning educational applications, implying that a sense of presence is important for education. Pantelidis (1993) gives a number of reasons, which apply to the use of VR in the classroom reporting active participation, high interactivity and individualisation as the main features for learning outcomes. Winn (1993) argues on a conceptual basis for educational applications of VR stating that immersive systems involve first-person experience and non-symbolic interaction, and support the construction of knowledge under a social constructivist point of view. The author proposes ‘size’, ‘transduction’ and ‘reification’ as the main characteristics of immersive VR as an educational tool. In later articles Winn and Windschitl (2000) extend their theoretical approach to desktop environments, referring to a sense of presence that students feel in the virtual environments.

There are a number of articles describing EVEs. There are many technological approaches that the EVEs follow, but few pedagogical ones. In general, the minority of research reports on the specific VR attributes that EVEs exploit. Thus, the essential characteristics that designate VR as a promising and powerful educational tool are not yet very clear.

Our group has reported on learning outcomes regarding science learning in virtual environments since 1998. Students interacting with an EVE on lake eutrophication felt a sense of presence (Mikropoulos et al. 1998). Since the particular EVE was not highly interactive, the sense of presence was a consequence of free navigation and first-person point of view. EIKON is an educational environment for the support of agricultural technology courses. High-school teachers who interacted with EIKON felt present in a collaborative environment that followed very good instructional design and used task-oriented objectives (Kameas et al. 2000). Our next EVE is designed for the support of the teaching of planetary phenomena (Bakas and Mikropoulos 2003). Twenty-seven students who navigated a spaceship created scientifically accepted mental models. The students felt a sense of presence, although the EVE was not immersive, attributing presence to the vivid colours of the virtual objects and the realistic movements of the celestial bodies. Plant cell biology is another project where 37 primary teachers interact with an EVE integrating the process of photosynthesis (Mikropoulos et al. 2003). The teachers indicated the importance of the learning tasks and reported a sense of presence as a result of free navigation and high degree of interactivity.

Salzman et al. (1999), have presented a model for understanding how VR aids complex conceptual learning in immersive EVEs for science learning. Although the authors have not studied how presence affects learning, they state that this is a promising topic for future research.

The Round Earth Project investigates how VR can be used to help teach concepts that are counter-intuitive to a learner’s currently held mental model (Johnson et al. 1999). Although 84 pupils felt a high sense of presence, the learning outcomes were limited.

There are also a number of other projects concerning EVEs for science learning that report or not on learning outcomes and the sense of presence within a limited framework. These include the NICE project (Roussos et al. 1999), the virtual solar system (Keating et al. 2002), an EVE for teaching about radioactivity (Crosier et al. 2002), and virtual water (Trindade et al. 2002). There are also quite a few EVEs for mathematics education that report learning outcomes (Pasqualotti and Freitas dal Sasso 2002).

Although some of the VR characteristics seem to make it especially applicable to science disciplines, the challenge for this medium is to show its pedagogical value in social disciplines too. The challenge becomes greater when we think of presence as an important factor for educational purposes in socialized, real or synthetic environments. Indeed, there are few EVEs regarding social sciences. Milton and Garbi (2000) have published the first results of a collaborative EVE for foreign language learning. It proved to be workable, but specific learning outcomes were not described. Antonietti and Cantoia (2000) have presented positive results on cognitive processes, letting students ‘get into’ a virtual representation of a painting.

There are many reports on the design and development of EVEs, but only some on the evaluation of learning outcomes. It seems that until now researchers have been interested in assessing features such as students’ attitude towards VR (Mikropoulos et al. 1998; Kameas et al. (2000); Bakas and Mikropoulos (2003); Mikropoulos et al. (2003), learning and interaction experience as well as learners’ characteristics (Mikropoulos et al. 1998; Kameas et al. 2000; Bakas and Mikropoulos 2003; Mikropoulos et al. 2003; Salzman et al. 1999; Crosier et al. 2002), usability (Mikropoulos and Strouboulis 2004; Roussos et al. 1999), collaboration (Keating et al. 2002; Milton and Garbi 2000), and the role of teacher (Mikropoulos et al. 2003; Keating et al. 2002). The few references to specific learning outcomes are mainly because few studies gather data on thinking processes, especially those required for learning procedures, although perceptual processes involved in VR have been investigated (Antonietti and Cantoia 2000). Moreover, specific learning goals are rarely specified. Researchers reporting on the pedagogical models for exploiting VR in education converge on constructivism with emphasis on social constructivism. This model is the most dominant in educational technology, and VR characteristics such as 3D spatial representations, autonomy, sensory modality, first-person point of view, freedom in navigation and interaction arise from this approach. These features also contribute to a sense of presence, which, however, is not studied extensively enough. The articles that ascribe the positive attitude of students and the learning outcomes to a sense of presence are few. The presence factors that seem to play an important role in EVEs are mainly form variables such as free navigation, first-person point of view, realism and interactivity (Mikropoulos et al. 1998; Bakas and Mikropoulos 2003; Mikropoulos et al. 2003). Content variables and especially the learning tasks also seem to play an important role (Kameas et al. 2000; Mikropoulos et al. 2003; Antonietti and Cantoia 2000).

In research that focuses on presence, the references to presence in EVEs and how it affects learning outcomes are also few. Heeter (1992) just mentions that children and adults may apply quite unrelated criteria for presence. She also implies that the different learning styles that are attributes of presence may have an important role in the design of EVEs and individualized learning. Ijsselsteijn (2004) states that cognitive processes like those created in EVEs, may powerfully influence and shape the sense of presence. Whitelock et al. (2000) report on social presence and indicates that the implications for concept learning are indirect.

It seems that presence is not studied in ways that allow us to explain its mechanisms or to understand how different types of presence have different effects on learning.

The present article investigates whether pupils’ sense of presence affects the expected learning outcomes intended for an EVE. Although the majority of our virtual learning environments concern science learning (Mikropoulos et al. 1998; Kameas et al. 2000; Bakas and Mikropoulos 2003; Mikropoulos et al. 2003), we now take up the challenge of social sciences and study an EVE for teaching and learning history.

Method

The virtual environment

Dynamic three-dimensional spatial representations integrate the proposals of Perkins (1991), for the design of computer-based learning environments for knowledge construction in history teaching. They contribute to the development of historical thinking, the understanding of the variety of the past, as well as the development of historic research skills. Thus, we have designed a place for the pupils to “be there” integrated with tasks “to do while there” for history learning.

The virtual environment is the representation of the ancient city of Kassiopi in Greece with all its buildings and a detailed house with two floors inhabited by avatars. It was developed with the Superscape VRT software on a personal computer. The display update rate was 25 Hz. The high-resolution information displayed to the participants with representations close to reality followed Steuer’s (1992) notion of vividness. Participants could navigate freely in the city, outside and inside the house (Figs. 1, 2). They could explore the architecture of the buildings and perform a series of tasks in the streets, the courtyard and the interior of the house. Participants navigated and performed the tasks through an avatar—their personal representation in the VE. The participant’s avatar was represented using two different models, the exocentric and the egocentric. For the exocentric model, the participant’s viewpoint was at a fixed point just behind the avatar (Fig. 1) and for egocentric it was what the avatar saw (Fig. 2). In both cases, the avatar’s movements reflected exactly the participant’s manipulations for navigation and interaction. Participants could walk through open doors or climb the staircases using their avatar. They could also pick up objects and handle them in certain locations inside and outside the house. All the above manipulations were performed using the computer keyboard with a one to one mapping of participant’s input to avatar orientation and position. This design decision was a result of an empirical study of six different input devices, a standard mouse, a joystick, a Space Mouse, the computer keyboard, the navigation bar of the software, and the combination of keyboard and mouse (Mikropoulos and Strouboulis 2004).

The research aims of the present study were:

  • to investigate if a sense of presence needed to live and interact in a virtual ancient city contributes to certain learning outcomes after performing certain learning tasks

  • to investigate if the combination of the participant’s model and the way the EVE is presented give a higher sense of presence that contributes to learning outcomes.

Procedure and sample

The learning tasks participants had to perform were analogous to those in a real ancient city. The story concerned the ancestor’s weapons, which the participant had to find and deposit in Zeus’ sanctuary. Participants had to navigate in the city and follow the oral instructions given by other avatars. They had to look for and collect specific objects, which have a certain educational and historical purpose such as coins and a purse, to locate a particular house and enter it. There, the participants had to gather some objects, and put them in their proper places and light the fire in the fireplace. Once participants had correctly completed all the tasks, the virtual householder appeared and rewarded by talking to them. In order to investigate the role of presence in the educational activities, these were rather simple. The participants had to listen to the virtual inhabitants all the time, follow their instructions to orientate correctly, to find the specific house, to find and collect the correct objects, to go to the right places. Inside the house the participants had to light the fire, to pick up, move and put some vases in certain places, to go to the upper floor and meet the housekeeper, to study the architecture and the activities of ancient people. For these activities, both the personal and social sense of presence had to be high.

The participants were 60 pupils (23 girls and 37 boys), aged between 11 and 13 years. The procedure consisted of two parts. The first part used the exocentric model and the second the egocentric. In both parts, the same virtual environment was projected on a wall in a darkened room and through a head-mounted display (HMD) with a head tracker to all the pupils. At the end of each part, each participant answered a questionnaire on presence and learning outcomes. The questionnaire was quite long including form, content and user characteristics variables integrating the factors of presence. In the present study we consider only the questions directly referring to personal, social presence and involvement in relation to learning outcomes and not those investigating the role of each factor. Besides the questionnaire the researcher’s observations were recorded, as well as the software’s log files describing the precise position and actions of the participants. The log files were automatically recorded from the software during the participants’ interactions in the EVE. For each object, a log file was created recording if the participant took an object, as well as how far from the correct location they placed it. These data gave a hint about space perception and the sense of presence inside the EVE. At the end of the pupils’ interaction with the ancient city, they answered four questions referring to the content of the EVE. Table 1 shows the questions directly associated with personal, social presence, involvement and content. The duration of the experiment for each pupil was 70 min.

Results and discussion

In the statistical analysis presented the t test was used in cases where the distributions are normal and the Wilcoxon Signed Ranks test where it was not.

Firstly we studied the pupils’ engagement with the avatar, their personal representation in the VE. This is a first indication of pupils’ sense of presence and involvement with the EVE. As Table 2 shows, all pupils’ answers were more than the mean value of 1 (not at all) to 5 (very much) -scale. The pupils felt fully engaged, wearing the HMD and acting through the egocentric model. As 72% of the pupils declared, they felt like being themselves in the avatar’s position and reported a “personal identification” with the avatar. All the pupils considered that their avatar was necessary for their presence, navigation and interaction inside the VE.

Figure 3 shows the number of pupils reporting a low (1–3) and high (4, 5) sense of personal presence (PP), when the EVE was projected on the wall. The mean values (and standard deviations) for PP1 were 4.05 (0.12) and 3.95 (0.13) for the exocentric and egocentric models, respectively. Based on Slater’s statement that an important feeling of “being there” is described by PP1, 83.4% of the pupils considered the VE as a place that they visited for the exocentric model and 76.7% for the egocentric model. The mean values for PP2 were also high, 3.72 (0.13) and 3.77 (0.12), for the exocentric and egocentric models, respectively. The mean values for PP3 were a little more than the middle of the scale, 2.57 (0.14) and 2.67 (0.16), respectively. Comparing the mean values of the three questions between the two models of the participant’s representation, no statistical significance was found (Z = −0.178, P > 0.05 (two-tailed)). This is an indication that the way the avatar represents the pupils in the EVE is not important in the case of the projection on the wall.

Figure 4 shows the number of pupils reporting low and high presence in the case of the HMD. For the exocentric model 65% of the pupils considered that they were themselves inside the virtual house and performed their tasks successfully. Moreover, 36.6% declared that there were moments that the VE was more realistic than the real environment. The mean values for PP1 was 4.05 (0.12), for PP2 3.63 (0.14) and for PP3 2.95 (0.16). The percentages concerning a high degree of presence were 81.7 and 55%, respectively for the egocentric model. The mean values for the three questions in the egocentric model were 3.95 (0.13), 4.20 (0.12) and 3.40 (0.09). The relatively low values for PP3, especially in the exocentric model could be explained by the degree of immersion the VR system can bring, assuming that presence is the response to a given level of immersion (Slater 2003). Higher values could be expected in a cave. In the case of the HMD, the participant’s representation model seems to play an important role in the sense of personal presence, with the egocentric model giving higher scores (Z = −3.848, P < 0.05 (two-tailed)). Comparing the mean values for each representation model we find that there is no statistical difference in personal presence between the VE projection and the HMD for the exocentric model (t = 1.347, df = 59, P > 0.05 (two-tailed)). For the egocentric model the HMD seems to play an important role, probably because of the higher degree of immersion (t = −3.548, df = 58, P < 0.05 (two-tailed) (Slater 2003). It seems that the focus of attention a HMD gives in combination with the egocentric model bring a feeling of “personal equation” of the user with their avatar. The pupils’ answers, the researcher’s observations and the software’s log files showed that the high sense of presence, especially in the case of the egocentric model and the HMD resulted in the correct completion of all the tasks. Some of the pupils’ comments were: “I was in a house and I was thinking that I myself was in there”, “I have been there! In ancient Greece!”, “I was in a house and I did some housework”, “I was in a place and I did some housework by myself”.

Social presence was studied only in the case of the EVE’s projection on the wall. This came as a result of a pilot study (Mikropoulos and Strouboulis 2004) as well as of the researcher’s observations during the pupils’ interactions with the avatars.

Figure 5 shows the number of pupils reporting a low (1–3) and high (4, 5) sense of social presence. Social presence (SP) was high for both the questions and representation models. The mean values of the answers were 4.13 (0.09) and 4.22 (0.08) for SP1 and SP2 for the exocentric model and 4.15 (0.08) and 4.22 (0.08) for the egocentric. The avatars’ instructions were found very helpful by 86.6% of the pupils, for completing their tasks, because they felt “being there” in the socialised virtual environment. Majority of the pupils (83.4%), declared that the avatars’ existence and communication helped them greatly to feel “being there”. Most of the pupils were answering avatars’ questions reporting their names and agreeing with their instructions. The pupils were also asking various questions and waiting for avatars’ responses. The pupils were communicating with the avatars orally. It seems that the pupils’ representation in the VE and its socialisation with autonomous avatars had the result of creating a “personal equation” of the pupils with their avatars. This gave a high sense of social presence and helped the pupils to complete their tasks correctly. All the pupils declared that the existence and communication of the autonomous avatars contributed greatly to navigating in the EVE without losing their orientation in the three dimensional space, to locating certain objects and the house, and completing their tasks. In a question “what did you like most?” the majority of the pupils answered the collaboration with the avatars and the satisfaction of doing the tasks the avatars told them to do.

Participants’ involvement (I) with the virtual environment is considered to be an important factor for the sense of presence, as well as for task performance.

Concerning the projection on the wall and the question I1, 17 pupils (28.3%) using the exocentric model and 19 pupils (31.7%), using the egocentric model forgot that they were in the real room, reported that they were present and working in the virtual city and showed a high degree of involvement (answers’ values 4 and 5). Regarding question I2, 17 pupils thought that their bodies were in the virtual house for the exocentric model. The number of pupils for the egocentric model was 25. This difference is statistically significant (Z = −2.373, P < 0.05 (two-tailed)), indicating that the participant’s representation model plays an important role in the involvement with the EVE. The total involvement combining both questions is relatively low in both cases, 2.61 (0.14) for the exocentric and 2.84 (0.15) for the egocentric model, not a significant difference (Z = −1.770, P > 0.05 (two-tailed)). In the case of the HMD the results were a little higher. The mean value for the exocentric model was 3.27 (0.16) with 25 pupils reporting that their body was involved in the EVE. The numbers were 3.70 (0.15) and 40 pupils for the egocentric model. This is a significant difference between the two models (Z = −2.741, P < 0.05 (two-tailed)). It seems that as in personal presence, the use of the HMD in combination with the egocentric model was responsible for this and that a fully immersive system would give even higher scores for presence and involvement. A similar result is shown with the comparison between projection and HMD. The difference in involvement is significant in both cases of the pupil’s representation model (Z = −3.650, P < 0.05 (two-tailed)), with the egocentric model giving the higher scores for involvement. Almost all the pupils reported that they enthused over their involvement with the tasks that they did “because they were there”.

Besides the context of an EVE, its content is very important for the information that gives and determines the learning tasks. In order to investigate if the sense of personal, social presence and involvement the pupils had with the EVE contributed to earning some more experiences beyond the specific tasks, the pupils answered some more questions after “living” in the ancient city (C1–C4, Table 1). Fifty-eight out of the 60 pupils answered correctly that the house walls were made of grey stone. Fifty-seven pupils found that the house staircases were wooden and 59 pupils answered that the fireplace that was in the middle of the ground floor warmed the inhabitants. Finally, 54 pupils noticed and described with accuracy the clothes of the ancient people. These answers are an indication that the pupils had a sense of “being there”, living and acting in a place other than their real environment.

Conclusions

The aim of this research was to investigate presence in educational virtual environments and especially presence in association with learning tasks and outcomes. To our knowledge, this is the first report on the contribution of the sense of presence as a unique characteristic of VR to learning outcomes with pupils.

From the results of the empirical study, we conclude that the pupils had a high sense of personal presence for both methods of presenting the EVE. Moreover, the existence of the avatar as the pupil’s representation contributed to this sense of personal presence and helped children to successfully perform their learning tasks. A controlled study using a no-avatar control group is needed in order to confirm this result. The way the EVE is presented to the pupils in combination with their representation model plays an important role in the sense of presence and the performance of the tasks. Although the sense of personal presence was high for all cases, the HMD together with the egocentric model gives better results.

The socialized virtual environment the pupils visited seems to play an important role in the learning outcomes, since more than 83% of the pupils found that the other avatars gave them a sense of a “living place”, communicated with them and responded to their instructions and hints. It is quite interesting that the other avatars contributed to a “personal equation” feeling the pupils reported with their avatar. This is also evidence for the correct performance of the pupils in the learning tasks.

The pupils’ involvement with the EVE contributes to a sense of presence, as well as to their positive learning outcomes. The HMD contributed to a greater involvement in both cases of the pupils’ representation model. As in the case of personal presence, the optimal combination is the HMD together with the egocentric model.

Figure 6 shows personal presence, social presence and involvement as functions of the type of EVE presentation and the participants’ representation model. The participants’ involvement with the EVE has the greater change through the four cases, with its higher mean value 3.70 (0.15) for the egocentric model with the use of the HMD. This is also the case where both personal and social presence, have their higher mean values, 3.85 (0.12) and 4.18 (0.09) respectively. The lowest value for personal presence is for the exocentric model and the HMD. It seems that the more immersive the system becomes, the more it cuts the pupil off from the real environment and gives them a sense of “personal equation” with their avatar, thus favouring the egocentric model for the pupils’ representation. The values of social presence are higher than those of personal presence and are independent of the way the EVE is presented and the pupils’ representation model. This is an indication that socialized virtual environments give a high sense of presence and should be preferred for educational applications. This is especially important when social constructivism is considered to be the theoretical model for learning through virtual environments.

Assuming that in the context of the present study personal presence, social presence and involvement do equally contribute to a total sense of presence, we can calculate the mean values of the total sense of presence in the EVE for the different experimental set-ups. These are 3.41 (0.09) for the exocentric and 3.50 (0.09) for the egocentric models and the VE projection, 3.58 (0.12) for the exocentric and 3.89 (0.13) for the egocentric models and the HMD. There is a significant difference between the projection and the HMD for both the exocentric (t = −3.361, df = 59, P < 0.05 (two-tailed)) and the egocentric (t = −6.271, df = 59, P < 0.05 (two-tailed)) models, showing that the HMD increases the sense of presence. The difference is not significant comparing the two representation models for the virtual environment projection on the wall (t = −1.299, df = 59, P > 0.05 (two-tailed)). However, the difference is significant in the case when the pupils use the HMD (t = −5.081, df = 59, P < 0.05 (two-tailed)). The highest sense of total presence is the case of the egocentric representation model together with the use of the HMD. Besides the statistics, this is corroborated by the pupils’ spontaneous expressions. Although the use of a HMD is not routine in VR educational applications at the moment, this could be exploited for the design of future EVEs. In general, the pupils had a high sense of presence interacting with our EVE and this helped them to perform their learning tasks successfully and work in a constructive learning environment. This is in line with the findings of Winn et al. (Winn et al. 1999) on student-built virtual environments. They reported that students’ enjoyment, ability to work in VE, success and their sense of presence were all interrelated.

Our results on social presence agree with those of Whitelock et al. (2000). In their empirical study they stated “... where collaboration was effective a strong sense of shared presence was reported and performances were improved”. This is in line with the high sense of social presence reported in the present study, corroborating that socialized and interactive EVEs may improve learning. In a systematic evaluation of evolving virtual learning environments, Selverian and Hwang (2003) state “levels of social presence may correlate with the achievement of higher-level learning objectives”. It seems that our results confirm their suggestion. Finally, our results concerning head tracking do not agree with those of Bystrom and Barfield (1999) who found that head tracking did not affect the sense of presence. This may be because their virtual environment was projected on a screen and not through a HMD, their subjects were adults, and their VE and tasks were without specific learning objectives.

It seems that the content of the VE together with specific learning tasks is an important factor affecting presence and task performance. Moreover, it seems that the statement of Heeter (1992) “children and adults may apply very unrelated criteria for presence” is confirmed by the results of our study.
